D.   Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program

The prevention program, which conforms to PSM/RMP requirements, consists of the following elements:

Employee Participation: This program involves the employees in establishing and implementing all aspects of the program.  Employees are involved when a process hazard analysis is conducted.  The program also ensures that all employees have complete access to the program.

Process Safety Information: Information has been collected which enables the employees to identify and understand the potential hazards in the refrigeration systems. The written information includes the ammonia SDS and a description of the design of the ammonia refrigeration systems.  Information is complete per the PSM/RMP requirements.

Process Hazard Analysis: Formal studies using the What-if and What-If/Checklist Techniques have been conducted to examine the ammonia refrigeration system and identify potential hazards.  PHAs are reviewed on a five-year basis. Any recommendations made either have been resolved or are part of ongoing work to improve facility safety.

Operating Procedures:  Written, detailed procedures have been developed which describe the steps which should be followed to safely operate the ammonia refrigeration system.  Procedures are reviewed annually and updated if necessary.

Training: A training program has been developed which ensures that employees are trained on all aspects of the system and on the duties which they should perform to ensure the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.
 
Contractors: All contractors are screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the ammonia refrigeration systems.  All contractors coming into the facilit

y are trained in evacuation procedures.  The contractors are also periodically evaluated to ensure that they perform work by following safe work practices.

Pre-Startup Safety Review: A pre-startup safety review is required for all new or modified ammonia refrigeration equipment and changes to the system.  The review verifies that all safety programs and procedures are in place, that training has been performed, and construction has been completed according to design standards before the project is put into use. They are also performed when there is a change in the process safety information.

Operating Procedures:  Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) are developed for each process covering all the equipment controls and process operations.  The SOPs are developed consistent with PSM/RMP requirements.

Mechanical Integrity:  This program ensures that the ammonia refrigeration systems are built and maintained using recommended and recognized preventive maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected breakdowns or failures.  Maintenance personnel are trained regularly, and spare parts and maintenance supplies are used which are consistent with good engineering practices and manufacturer's recommendations.

Hot Work Permit: This permitting procedure for all hot work ensures that a signed permit is obtained prior to any cutting, welding, or burning; this indicates that all necessary precautions have been taken.

Management of Change: Procedures are designed to ensure that all changes made to the ammonia refrigeration systems are properly reviewed for safety and against Best Engineering Practices criterion, that all the necessary and required information is obtained updated and that safety evaluations, e.g. PHA, have been performed.  This procedure works with the Pre-Startup Safety Review to ensure that any changes implemented are properly reviewed and managed.

A.   Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Tip Top Poultry, Marietta Facility, recognizes management's responsibility in protecting its employees, the public, the environment, equipment, and property.  The safety and health of all personnel are of primary importance.  The control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the Marietta facility.

To accomplish the company's goal in preventing accidents, the facility has established a Plant Safety Program.  The objectives of the Plant Safety Program are to: maximize safety performance, eliminate human suffering resulting from injuries and accidents and reduce losses associated with damage of property.

One of the activities associated with the Plant Safety Program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, 29 CFR 1910.119), and EPA's Risk Management Program (RM program) regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68). The Plant Manager is responsible for implementation of the Risk Management Program.

The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emergency response program is to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of anhydrous ammonia, including exposure, fire or explosion.  Overall, these programs help prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses, environmental impacts and physical property damage.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs help prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices which govern individual processes, activities, and/or equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the

facility.

In addition to required safety programs, the Marietta, GA facility has additional safety programs and process including:

- Corporate Safety Management System modeled after OSHAS 1800.
- Central Safety Committee 
- Hourly Safety Committees
- Safety Audits conducted by both Salary and Hourly Employees

B.   Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Tip Top Poultry, Marietta, GA facility is a chicken processing facility which receives live chickens and processes them for distribution via slaughter, chilling, cutup, packaging, and then chilling or freezing them.  The facility operates two separate ammonia refrigeration systems to provide cooling and freezing capabilities for processing and storage areas.  The amount of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7662-41-7) contained in the combined systems is in excess of 10,000 pounds.  The inventory in the Engine Room 1 system is approximately 12,000 pounds.  The inventory in the Engine Room 3 system is approximately 12,000 pounds giving a combined total of 24,000 lbs. 

The Engine Room 1 system is a High/Intermediate pressure system used to cool processes and workspaces throughout the facility.  The Engine Room 3 system is a Intermediate/Low pressure system used to cool docks and storage areas and provide refrigeration for Freezers operating down to -30 deg. F.

An ammonia release from the system poses a risk of offsite public and/or environmental injury or impact.  The system is regulated under the OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119).  The system is subject to the Program 3 requirements of the EPA's RMP (40 CFR Part 68) program.

E.   Five-Year Accident History

The facility has had 1 incident involving a reportable releases (over 100 lbs.) in the past 5 years.   The incident occurred on 9-13-16 due to a high condenser pressure causing a relief valve (PRV) to lift.
